required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Time Serial Analysis on Preemptive Analgesia of Preoperative Topical Diclofenac and Ketorolac in Photorefractive Keratectomy(PRK)

brief_summary.textblock: The investigators performed this study to investigate pain prevention of preoperative topical nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) in photorefractive keratectomy(PRK) using time serial pain scoring.

primary_outcome.measure: Pain score using visual analog scale(VAS) of each topical NSAIDs pre-treated eyes.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Change the VAS level at 6, 18, 24, 36, 48, 72, and 96 hours after ketorolac in photorefractive keratectomy(PRK)
primary_outcome.description: Through these postoperative pain score which rated time serially, the effect of pre-treated topical NSAIDs(ketorolac and diclofenac) could be investigated on relieving postoperative pain after PRK.

arm_group.description: (ketorolac 0.5% in one eye, ofloxacin 0.3% in the other eye)
(diclofenac 0.1% in one eye, ofloxacin 0.3% in the other eye)

intervention.intervention_name: topical ketorolac 0.5% (Acular®, Allergan Inc, Irvine, CA)
intervention.description: On operation day, the patients were randomly assigned to one of the following two groups: group KO,preoperative application of topical ketorolac 0.5% (Acular®, Allergan Inc, Irvine, CA) in one eye and topical ofloxacin 0.3% (Ocuflox®, SamilInc, Seoul, Korea)in the other eye; group DO, topical diclofenac 0.1% (Voltaren®, Novartis, Bern, Switzerland) in one eye and ofloxacin 0.3% in the other eye. Neither the surgeon nor the participants knew which ophthalmic would go to which eye. A randomly assigned ophthalmic was instilled into right eye first three times by 1 minute interval 30 minutes prior to operation and the other ophthalmic was instilled into left eye with the same manner 10 minute later.

On operation day, the patients were randomly assigned to one of the following two groups: group KO,preoperative application of topical ketorolac 0.5% (Acular®, Allergan Inc, Irvine, CA) in one eye and topical ofloxacin 0.3% (Ocuflox®, SamilInc, Seoul, Korea)in the other eye; group DO, topical diclofenac 0.1% (Voltaren®, Novartis, Bern, Switzerland) in one eye and ofloxacin 0.3% in the other eye. Neither the surgeon nor the participants knew which ophthalmic would go to which eye. A randomly assigned ophthalmic was instilled into right eye first three times by 1 minute interval 30 minutes prior to operation and the other ophthalmic was instilled into left eye with the same manner 10 minute later.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. at least 19 years of age
2. simultaneous bilateral PRK schedule
3. more than 400μm(including epithelium) of postoperative corneal thickness
4. less than 150μm of ablation depth.
Exclusion Criteria:
1. a history of ocular surgery or trauma
2. two-diopter more difference in spherical equivalent (SE) between the eyes, 3. keratoconus or other corneal pathology
4. use of systemic or topical NSAID within 1 month before the surgery 5. history of allergic reaction to aspirin or other NSAIDs 6. glaucoma or ocular hypertension (> 20 mmHg) 7. collagen vascular diseases 8. diabetic retinopathy 9. pregnancy or lactation 10. intraoperative complications.

facility.name: Departement of Ophthalmology, Yonsei University College of Medicine
